1,000 ppm by 2100 under certain scenarios, primarily driven by anthropogenic sources. Technology that can capture CO2 from anthropogenic sources, remove it from the atmosphere, and sequester it at the gigaton scale by 2050 is required to stop and reverse the impact of climate change. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been a promising technology in various applications, including gas separation and CO2 capture from point-source flue gases or removal from the atmosphere. MOFs offer an unmatched surface area through their highly porous crystalline structure, and MOF technology has the potential to become a leading adsorption-based CO2 separation technology, providing high surface area, structure stability, and chemical tunability.

Due to its complex structure, MOF crystal structure (atoms and bonds) cannot be easily represented in tabular format for machine learning (ML) applications. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have already been explored in the representation of simpler chemical molecules. In addition to the difficulty in MOF data representation, an infinite number of combinations can be created for MOF crystals, making ML applications more suitable to alleviate dependency on subject matter experts (SMEs) than conventional computational methods.

In this work, we propose training of GNNs in a variational autoencoder (VAE) setting to create an end-to-end workflow for the generation of new MOF crystal structures directly from the data within the crystallographic information files (CIFs) and conditioned by additional CO2 performance values.

Limiting global warming to 1.5°C implies that net anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions worldwide decline by about 45% from 2010 levels by 2030 and reach net-zero by 2050 (IPCC, 2018). To achieve this target while ensuring a smooth energy transition, we need to reduce emissions from hard-to-abate industrial CO2 sources such as power, cement, steel, and chemical plants. In this journey, CO2 capture, utilization, and sequestration (CCUS) will play a vital role by capturing at the sources and permanently storing in the subsurface.

However, this ambitious goal requires global deployment of CO2 capture plants at a very large scale, increasing capture capacity from 40 million tonnes per annum (Mtpa) today to 5,635 Mtpa by 2050 (Global CCS Institute, 2020). In the capture process, we must separate CO2 molecules from other gases present in the gas stream coming out of a power plant or an industrial facility. Several well-established separation technologies exist to remove CO2 from various emission sources, with solvent-based absorption technology being the most mature and deployed at an industrial scale (Leung et al., 2018).

The capture processes operating with aqueous amine (e.g., monoethanolamine) solvents, however, are plagued by high energy costs associated with solvent regeneration. The corrosive nature of amine solvents and emission of toxic amines with the treated gas are also challenges that need attention (Oko et al., 2017). To address these challenges, researchers have developed alternative solvents, such as non-aqueous and bi-phasic solvents. Apart from the solvent performance, the large size of absorption and desorption columns required in solvent-based capture plants imposes high capital expenditure.

As a result, CO2 separation techniques using solid sorbents, membranes, and cryogenics have been developed and tested at the laboratory scale and pilot scale (Abanades et al., 2015). Extensive research and development activities have been ongoing for the last two to three decades to increase the technical maturity of these nascent technologies and to reduce the cost of capture at an industrial scale. Despite these efforts, there is a strong demand for new material development to improve the CO2 capture capacity and selectivity over other gases and to reduce the regeneration energy need.

There is an urgent need to develop new materials for CO2 capture with the objective of lowering the cost of CO2 capture and the energy penalty. Different classes of materials are being explored for this application for their CO2 selectivity, affinity towards CO2, and capture density. MOFs come across as promising candidates due to their large surface area, flexibility in tuning surface properties for selectivity, tunable porous structure, and scalability for industrial use. MOFs can offer efficient CO2 adsorption in a highly porous crystalline structure, which can also provide stability and tunability.
